dt: {bc}the act, process, or result of fixing, {a_link|fixating}, or becoming {a_link|fixated}: such as
{bc}a persistent concentration of libidinal energies upon objects characteristic of psychosexual stages of development preceding the genital stage
{bc}an obsessive or unhealthy preoccupation or attachment

et: Middle English {it}fixacioun{/it} "(in alchemy) reduction of a volatile substance to a form not alterable by fire or another agent of change," borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}fīxātiōn-, fīxātiō,{/it} from {it}fīxāre{/it} "to so reduce a volatile substance" (verbal derivative of Latin {it}fīxus{/it} "firmly established, unchangeable") + Latin {it}-tiōn-, -tiō,{/it} suffix of action nouns; in psychological senses after German {it}Fixation{/it} or {it}Fixierung{/it} {ma}{mat|fix:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: the act, process, or result of fixing, fixating, or becoming fixated: such as
a persistent concentration of libidinal energies upon objects characteristic of psychosexual stages of development preceding the genital stage
stereotyped behavior (as in response to frustration)

dt: {bc}the process of binding serum complement to the product formed by the union of an antibody and the antigen for which it is specific that occurs when complement is added to a suitable mixture of such an antibody and antigen and that is the basis of some tests to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens

shortdef: the process of binding serum complement to the product formed by the union of an antibody and the antigen for which it is specific that occurs when complement is added to a suitable mixture of such an antibody and antigen and that is the basis of some tests to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens

dt: {bc}the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into a combined form (such as ammonia) through chemical and especially biological action (such as that of soil rhizobia)

shortdef: the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into a combined form (such as ammonia) through chemical and especially biological action (such as that of soil rhizobia)
